head.title: Tidbit; For the Happy Couple, a Hope Chest of Pasta

hedline.hl1: Tidbit; For the Happy Couple, a Hope Chest of Pasta

abstract.p: Zingerman's in Ann Arbor, Mich, one of best fancy-food shops in country, now has bridal registry, with variety of food items that could be used as wedding presents (S)

block.p: BRIDAL gifts usually have a certain durability, even permanance: the Limoges, the Waterford, the Calphalon. They're important, expensive. But, hey, these are the 1990's, and marriages aren't what they used to be.
And apparently neither are some wedding presents.

BRIDAL gifts usually have a certain durability, even permanance: the Limoges, the Waterford, the Calphalon. They're important, expensive. But, hey, these are the 1990's, and marriages aren't what they used to be.
And apparently neither are some wedding presents.

Zingerman's in Ann Arbor, Mich., one of the best fancy-food shops in the country, has a new bridal registry. Couples who prefer to stock the pantry instead of the china cabinet can register for extra virgin olive oils (a matched set of five costs $150), rare German vinegars ($100 to $145 a bottle), pasta and sauces (one set is $48), or a collection of basic items, including sea salt, peppercorns, Spanish paprika and Mexican hot chocolate ($50 to $220). The bridal registry is also available through the Zingerman's catalogue, which can be sent to wedding guests for consideration. Information: (888) 636-8162.

Recently, a couple from Seattle registered for a grab bag of nonperishables: oil, vinegar, honey, salt and pasta sauce. No, gifts like this do not last as long as a silver bowl from Aunt Tillie, but maybe it's just as nice to have some great olives to put in the bowl.
